input2:
She initially presented to her PCP early last week after noticing "phlebitis" of the left lower leg. This was thought to be related to her h/o varicose veins and so was advised to continue monitoring. At that time also had increased frequency of palpitations (with known history of paroxysmal a-tach) and so metoprolol was doubled and received Holter monitor. Later that week developed worsening dyspnea to the point that she was unable to walk across a parking lot without losing her breath. This was very unusual for her, as at baseline she is very active and had even completed a hiking trip. 
﻿
Her PCP referred her where she was found to have be hypoxic but otherwise hemodynamically stable. Labs revealed D-dimer elevation 7.2, troponin-I elevation to 0.815, NT proBNP elevated at 2374. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with anterior lateral TWI (V2-V6). CT chest showed moderate bilateral pulmonary emboli with the largest being in the right lower lobe, mild RV dilation, with main pulmonary artery dilated 3.6 cm.  Echocardiogram was obtained prior to transfer which was significant for positive sign, moderately dilated right ventricle, with moderately reduced RV function. LV function was normal.
﻿
She was subsequently transferred where hospital course was notable for multiple episodes of SVT with rates into the 160s. Repeat troponin-T was reassuring at 0.02. ICU team was consulted for consideration thrombolytics which were felt to be unnecessary. Per family request, she was subsequently transferred for further evaluation.
﻿
Upon arrival to the ICU, she reports feeling overall well but continues to be mildly dyspneic. Did have mild episode of vague chest pain earlier last week but that has since resolved. No other new symptoms at this time. She thinks she is up to date onroutine cancer screening, including colonoscopy, Pap, and mammogram, though exact details are somewhat unclear and with further questioning is not entirely confident. No recent operations or significant immobilization. No family history of clotting disorders. No personal history of intracranial or other significant bleeding disorders.
﻿
10-point review of systems was negative except as detailed above.
﻿
input3:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS  
+ hypertension

2. CARDIAC HISTORY  
+ paroxysmal atrial tachycardia

3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 
+ remote history of L face melanoma s/p excision
+ migraines
+ varicose veins
input4: No known family history of clotting or bleeding disorders.

Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM
GENERAL: Well appearing woman in no acute distress. Comfortable.
NEURO: AAOx3. Moving all four extremities with purpose.
HEENT: NCAT. EOMI. MMM.
CARDIAC: Irregular rhythm, normal rate. Normal S1/S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. JVP ~8 cm at 45 deg.
PULMONARY: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Breathing comfortably on room air.
ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
EXTREMITIES: Warm, well perfused, non-edematous. 
SKIN: No significant rashes.
﻿
General: NAD, alert and interactive
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Sclera anicteric and without injection. 
Neck: Supple.
Lungs: CTAB, normal work of breathing.
CV: Regular rhythm, normal rate. Audible S1 and S2. No murmurs/rubs/gallops.
GI: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normal bowel sounds. No rebound or guarding.
Ext: Warm and well perfused. No peripheral edema. 
Neuro: AOx3
﻿

Imaging:
Thoracic ECHO :
The patient is hemodynamically stable
IMPRESSION: Mild right ventricular cavity dilation with basal hypokinesis and relative preservation of apical motion sign) and septal flattening during systole/diastole due to right ventricular pressure/volume overload. Normal left ventricular wall thickness, cavity size, and regional/global systolic function. Increased PCWP. Mild aortic regurgitation. Mild mitral regurgitation. Mild to moderate tricuspid regurgitation. At least moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
﻿
Lower Extremity Doppler U/S:
IMPRESSION:  
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right or left lower extremity veins. 
﻿
CXR on admission:
Lungs are hyperinflated but clear.  Heart size top-normal. No pleural abnormality. 
﻿
